Here’s a detailed overview of the codebase.

It’s organized into a backend built on FastAPI and a frontend built with React. The backend provides the core agent logic, API modules, tool integrations, and voice functionality. It uses AutoGen (v0.5.x) for the agent runtime, with WebSocket streaming and dynamic selection of model clients like OpenAI or Gemini. The backend also manages a voice stack with a WebRTC bridge to OpenAI Realtime, allowing multiple browser clients to share a session.

The frontend is a React app with Material UI theming, routing, and pages for agent dashboards, a tool editor, and voice dashboards. It uses React 18, Material UI 5, Monaco Editor, Axios, and React Router v6.

The project structure includes:
- Backend subfolders for configs, core agent logic, API modules, tool implementations, JSON configs, and tests.
- Frontend organized by features, for agents, tools, and voice dashboards, plus shared components.

Key dependencies on the backend include FastAPI, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google generative clients, AutoGen, ChromaDB, and voice/WebRTC libraries like aiortc and pipecat. There’s also a separate Node package for Puppeteer-based screenshots and voice DB exports.

Tests are split into unit and integration tests under the backend, with a runner orchestrating the test execution.

This gives a solid starting point for analyzing or extending the project.

It wraps up with troubleshooting tips, file locations, common commands, and links to more detailed guides.

Yes, I understand your vision. You want a frontend page that can dynamically load and display an HTML file, which is generated or selected by the agent. Each file would be named in a straightforward way, and the frontend page would refresh or reload when the file changes. The reference to which file to load could be stored in a JSON file or somewhere accessible, so the frontend knows which HTML file to present. Yes, please proceed.

At this point, everything’s in place for the agent to generate new HTML files and for the frontend to display them dynamically.
